title.rendered: Vaughan Plumbing Services: Why Toilet Maintenance is Important

content.rendered:
There are certain fixtures in the home that remain in the background unless something goes wrong with them; the toilet is one such fixture. When searching for “home repairs near me,” you will likely find that most repair offerings have to do with plumbing. When a toilet is not functioning properly, it interferes with family life. 

A toilet is one device in the house that you do not want to fail ever. In order to reduce the risk of something going wrong, you need to take care of the toilet and ensure it is correctly maintained. 

Importance of Toilet Maintenance

According to Vaughan plumbing services, toilet maintenance is a vital and often neglected aspect of home care. While most people clean their toilets routinely, sanitation is not the only thing you need to worry about. You also need to consider drain cleaning, wax ring replacements, fixture upkeep, etc.  

Ignoring maintenance tasks will likely lead to significant problems. Potential plumbing issues might include backups, overflows, etc. If you are not sure how to correctly care for your toilet, contact a plumber for advice. 

Preventing Toilet Damage

While toilets are essential features of indoor plumbing and are quite durable, they are vulnerable and susceptible to damage. People often abuse their toilets without realizing it. For many people, taking care of a toilet is only about cleaning it and flushing it. However, people often forget to consider the things they flush down the drains. Your toilet is only part of a larger drainage system. If you misuse your toilet, you are likely putting unnecessary strain on your system. Therefore, there are a few things to keep in mind. 

1. Only Flushable Products Go Down the Drain

The only products that should go down a toilet drain are toilet paper and specified cleaners. You want to avoid flushing anything that does not specifically say it is flushable and septic-safe. You want to be careful because some products will say flushable but they won’t say septic safe. If you are ever in doubt about a product you want to flush, contact a local plumber.  

Additionally, if you have children, keep a close eye when they are playing around bathrooms. Children are very curious by nature and they often like to see what toys or items will flush. 

2. Be Careful About Chemical Selection

When a toilet is dirty or clogged, it is tempting to use the strongest chemical cleaner you can find, but the wrong kind of chemicals can be corrosive, potentially damaging your toilet and drains. Additionally, the wrong combination of chemicals can become volatile and potentially explosive, possibly damaging your drains. To avoid extensive plumbing damage, you want to be careful about chemical use; it is often best to contact a plumber for assistance because they will know what products are safe. 

3. Keep It Clean

Hygiene and sanitation are crucial elements of toilet maintenance. You want to clean your toilet at least once a week, possibly more depending on the number of people using it and the frequency of use. Cleaning a toilet is not only about eliminating bacteria, it is also about maintaining properly functioning components. A clean toilet tends to work well. However, routine cleaning is not the same as a thorough drain cleaning, which should occur at least once per year.

When is the last time you really thought about your toilet? While everyone uses a toilet multiple times per day, they rarely consider the health of the mechanisms that operate the device. If it has been a long time since you had a plumbing inspection, or if you are experiencing problems with your toilet, contact Handyman Connection and speak with a licensed plumber.
